title: Burger King staff refuse to read ingredients to blind woman with severe allergy
text:

A blind woman with a severe food allergy claims Burger King staff refused to read the list of ingredients on the menu to her.

Now the fast food chain have been forced to apologise and say they will get to the bottom of exactly what happened.

Medina Hall visited the Folkestone branch of the burger restaurant in Kent and explained why she needed assistance.

Outlining why she needed to know the details of what went into their brownie, detailing her nut allergy, she asked for help.

She was then told by staff that they were not allowed to read out details of the menu to her.

Medina says workers claimed it was "company policy" and meant "all customers had to read it themselves".

Burger King said there is no such policy in place - and that they were now looking into this matter further.

"I was shocked," she told the BBC . "If I had I eaten it and it had nuts in, I would have had a major asthma attack and ended up in hospital.

"In today's day and age you'd think they would want to read it and get it right."

Burger King say they will now look into it and find out why staff refused to help the woman.

A spokesman said: "We would firstly like to apologise to Medina, her experience this week is not reflective of the high standards we would expect within any of our restaurants.

(Image: Getty Images)

"Everyone should have an enjoyable experience when they visit us and we are looking into this matter further.

"I can also confirm that there is no such policy to refrain from reading allergen information to visually-impaired customers."

It's not the first time Burger King has been in the headlines in October.

This week a tweet has been banned by the advertising watchdog for condoning antisocial behaviour and encouraging political protesters to “milkshake” Brexit party leader Nigel Farage.

It read: “Dear people of Scotland. We’re selling milkshakes all weekend. Have fun. Love BK. #justsaying”.

(Image: Getty Images)

Farage had previously been caked in milkshake in Newcastle.

“We considered that the tweet was likely to be seen as a reference to the recent incidents of ‘milkshaking’ political figures,” said the Advertising Standards Authority.

“We considered that the ad condoned the previous antisocial behaviour and encouraged further instances.

"We therefore concluded the ad was irresponsible. We told Burger King to ensure that its future marketing communications did not condone or encourage antisocial behaviour.”
description: The fast food giants say their employees in Folkstone, Kent, were wrong to tell Medina Hall that "all customers had to read menus themselves"
